entry.title: Indonesian community praised for rescuing Rohingya refugee

media:group.media:title: Indonesian community praised for rescuing Rohingya refugee
media:group.media:description:
A group of Rohingya refugees rescued by fishermen in Indonesian waters has disembarked in the province of Aceh. Ninety-nine people were on board the vessel, including 28 children. Human rights groups have praised the local community for their efforts, but say governments in the region must do more to protect Rohingya refugees. Al Jazeera's Jessica Washington reports from Jakarta, Indonesia.

entry.title: Lebanon's economy: Central Bank tries to stabilise exchange rate

media:group.media:title: Lebanon's economy: Central Bank tries to stabilise exchange rate
media:group.media:description:
Lebanon's Central Bank is launching an electronic foreign exchange trading platform, in an attempt to stabilise the exchange rate. The lira has lost nearly 70 percent of its value on the black market in recent months, due to a lack of foreign currency. Al Jazeera's Zeina Khodr reports.

entry.title: ASEAN summit: Post-pandemic economic recovery dominates talks

media:group.media:title: ASEAN summit: Post-pandemic economic recovery dominates talks
media:group.media:description:
The leaders of Southeast Asian countries are calling for a unified response to the coronavirus pandemic to ensure a strong economic recovery. They have been meeting by video link Association of Southeast Asian Nations for their latest summit hosted by Vietnam which, so far, has responded to the virus better than most countries. Al Jazeera's Wayne Hay reports from Bangkok, Thailand.

entry.title: Malawi election: Activists closely monitor vote counting

media:group.media:title: Malawi election: Activists closely monitor vote counting
media:group.media:description:
Malawi's opposition candidate Lazarus Chakwera has claimed victory in the rerun of last year's presidential election. Early results have put him ahead of the incumbent, Peter Mutharika. Al Jazeera's Haru Mutasa reports.

entry.title: UN anniversary: 75 years since UN charter was signed

media:group.media:title: UN anniversary: 75 years since UN charter was signed
media:group.media:description:
The United Nations is celebrating the 75th anniversary of its founding document. Some 50 countries gathered in San Francisco to sign the UN Charter in 1945. Today, it has 193 member states. Al Jazeera's James Bays reports.

entry.title: Bill to give Washington, DC statehood gets historic US vote

media:group.media:title: Bill to give Washington, DC statehood gets historic US vote
media:group.media:description:
The US House of Representatives is due to vote on whether to grant full statehood to Washington, DC, the nation's capital. If it passes the House and then the Senate, the District of Columbia's more than 700,000 residents would finally have representation and full voting rights in Congress. Al Jazeera's Mike Hanna reports.

entry.title: Iraq's historic marshes: Outbreak threatens community of herders

media:group.media:title: Iraq's historic marshes: Outbreak threatens community of herders
media:group.media:description:
The coronavirus pandemic is affecting a community in Iraq's historic marshes. For years, people there have relied on the wetlands for herding water buffaloes. But the pandemic is now threatening their livelihood. Al Jazeera’s Katia Lopez-Hodoyan reports.

entry.title: ICC to launch investigation into war crimes by Israel

media:group.media:title: ICC to launch investigation into war crimes by Israel
media:group.media:description:
The International Criminal Court’s prosecutor is expected to launch an investigation into potential war crimes committed by Israelis. The court's pre-trial chamber is looking at what jurisdiction it has over illegally occupied Palestinian territory. Palestinians have long called for the ICC to begin examining cases. Al Jazeera’s Nida Ibrahim spoke to a family whose son was killed near Bethlehem.

entry.title: US coronavirus cases may be up to 10 times higher than data shows

media:group.media:title: US coronavirus cases may be up to 10 times higher than data shows
media:group.media:description:
The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention believes the true number of Americans infected by COVID-19 could be nearly 10 times higher than the 2.3 million cases that have been confirmed. The country recorded its biggest daily increase in new cases on Thursday. Some states are now pausing efforts to reopen their economies. Al Jazeera’s Rob Reynolds reports.

entry.title: Can the US stop Huawei's expansion? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Can the US stop Huawei's expansion? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
The United States says it's willing to finance other countries' 5G networks, so long as Huawei is not involved. President Donald Trump accuses Beijing of using its influence over Chinese companies to spy on other countries. In the UK, Huawei has been given permission to build a new research facility. That's while the country's cyber security agency conducts an emergency review into the use of Huawei's 5G equipment. The Chinese firm says it will invest more than a billion dollars in its new site in the east of England. While insisting the focus will be on the development and manufacturing of semi-conductors. Which according to Huawei - are not targeted by US sanctions. But Washington has warned the British government that the decision to approve the new project, will put its trust in the UK at risk. So, are there legitimate concerns? Or is this another attempt to fend off China's expansion?
Presenter: Bernard Smith
Guests:
John Biggs - Reporter for TechCrunch.
Andy Mok - Senior Research Fellow at the Center for China and Globalization.
Nishanth Sastry - Visiting Researcher at the Alan Turing Institute at the University of Surrey in the UK.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Huawei #US

entry.title: Brazil's outbreak: Health workers struggle to reach remote areas

media:group.media:title: Brazil's outbreak: Health workers struggle to reach remote areas
media:group.media:description:
Brazil has announced almost another 40,000 cases and more than 1,000 deaths over the past 24 hours. President Jair Bolsonaro has said that he may have had the virus, even though he tested negative. Healthcare workers are struggling to control the spread of COVID-19 in rural areas. Al Jazeera’s Manuel Rapalo reports.

entry.title: Pakistan airline suspends 150 pilots over alleged licence fraud

media:group.media:title: Pakistan airline suspends 150 pilots over alleged licence fraud
media:group.media:description:
Pakistan's national carrier has grounded a third of its pilots after an investigation found they may have cheated to get their licences. The fraud came to light during an investigation into a plane crash that killed 97 people in May. Al Jazeera’s Osama Bin Javaid reports.

entry.title: Assassinations, nuclear tests, hugs: 70 years of the Korean War

media:group.media:title: Assassinations, nuclear tests, hugs: 70 years of the Korean War
media:group.media:description:
The Korean War broke out 70 years ago. It has never officially ended, leaving tension between the North and the South. A ceremony to mark the anniversary has been held on an airbase in Cheorwon, near Seoul, as calls continue for peace. Al Jazeera’s Rob McBride reports.

entry.title: Rohingya plight, COVID-19 high on ASEAN summit

media:group.media:title: Rohingya plight, COVID-19 high on ASEAN summit
media:group.media:description:
The plight of the Rohingya is expected to be included on the agenda of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations meeting on Friday. Other topics likely to dominate the discussions include the reopening of borders after the coronavirus lockdown and the territorial dispute in the South China Sea. Al Jazeera's Florence Looi has more from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

entry.title: Will Vladimir Putin be president of Russia for life? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Will Vladimir Putin be president of Russia for life? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
Vladimir Putin was first elected as Russia's president in 2000. Twenty years later he's still there. He's served longer than any Russian or Soviet politician since the early 1950s. And he could be on course to be one of his nation's longest serving leaders. Putin's opponents say he plans to never leave office. Constitutional reforms introduced in January will allow him to stay in power for another two six-year terms. His current one ends in four years. Russians have started voting in a week-long referendum on the amendments. But the state Duma has already approved those changes to the constitution- while also passing a law that said, the reforms must have the public's support.
So, how will this shape Russia's future?
Presenter: Bernard Smith
Guests:
Andrei Fedorov - Director of Fund for Political Research and Consulting and former Deputy Foreign Minister of Russia.
Jim Jatras - A former U.S. Diplomat who served at the USSR desk at the State Department and a former Foreign Policy Advisor to the U.S. Senate Republican Leadership Attorney.
Alexander Solovyev - Moscow Division Chairman at the Party of Changes and a former Assistant to the Independent Member of Parliament Dmitry Gudkov.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
